misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different program instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit this distance-between-points program for the grade calculator question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade value from the user and use conditional statements to map the numeric range to the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, F), then print that letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a numeric grade
No conditional logic (if/else) to handle grade ranges
Output is a distance value, not a letter grade
None of the rubric requirements for grade calculation are present
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between exercises or reusing a previous template without adapting it to the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance calculation logic and instead write a new program that reads a single integer or double grade, uses an if-else-if chain to check the specified ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.), and prints the appropriate letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to computing point distance and contains no elements related to grade input or letter-grade mapping.

evidence.note: Code computes distance between two points; there is no reading of a grade, no conditional checks for ranges, and no letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation (Wrong Problem Solved)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. Consequently, none of the logic required by the rubric (grade input, conditional grading, letter grade output) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student submitted code for an entirely different problem (Distance Between Points) rather than the requested Grade Calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading a single integer input (0-100) representing a grade and outputting a specific letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on conditional ranges.
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (coordinates) instead of one integer input (grade)
Code calculates Euclidean distance
No conditional logic (if/else if) is present
Output is a floating-point number, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely submitted the wrong file or misunderstood the required assignment for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem description for Q3 and ensure the submitted code addresses the Grade Calculator task, which requires reading a single numeric grade and using conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly solves the distance formula problem, which confirms it does not address the Grade Calculator requirement at all.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating the distance between two points (reading 4 coordinates and using the distance formula), completely ignoring the requirement to calculate a letter grade based on a single numeric input.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solution
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have misunderstood the assignment and implemented a distance calculation program instead of a grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance using Math.sqrt and Math.pow instead of grade logic
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' not related to grade calculation
No conditional logic for grade ranges (no if/else for A/B/C/D/F)
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have copied code from a previous assignment, misread the problem statement, or submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to read ONE numeric grade and use if-else statements to determine the corresponding letter grade based on the five ranges (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, C: 70-79, D: 60-69, F: below 60).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves an entirely different problem with no overlap to the grade calculator requirements. This is clear from the class name, input prompts, variable names, and calculation logic.

evidence.note: Entire submission is code for a distance calculator, not a grade calculator. No grade input, no letter grade logic, no conditional statements for grade ranges.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (distance calculator instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points using four double inputs instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade with conditionals as required by the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that asks for two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade from 0–100 and use conditional statements to print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value.
No variable represents a grade or letter grade.
No conditional (if/else) logic to map ranges to letter grades.
Output describes distance between points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different exercises or reuse of a prior template without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and start by identifying the required input (one numeric grade), the decision logic (grade ranges mapped to letters), and the required output format. Then rewrite main to follow this structure using if/else-if/else statements.
related_concepts: Designing input and output for a specific task
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and all variables are dedicated to computing point distance, with no mention of grades or letter mapping.

evidence.note: The code reads four doubles representing two points and prints their distance, with no handling of a single grade input or letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect problem attempt
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. The code does not attempt to read a single numeric grade, nor does it contain any grading logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student submitted code solving the distance calculation problem, possibly believing it was the required task, or they mistakenly uploaded the wrong file/block of code for Q3.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to implement a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and prints the corresponding letter grade using conditional statements (if/else or switch).
symptoms: Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of a letter grade.
Input consists of four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade.
Output is a floating-point number (distance) instead of a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or misreading the problem prompt (Q3 vs perhaps Q1/Q2), or submitting the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the instructions for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and implement the necessary logic for reading a single numeric grade and using conditional statements to determine the letter grade based on the required ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The provided code, class name, input prompts, and calculation clearly correspond to solving the distance formula, which is entirely different from the Grade Calculator task described in the prompt.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a different problem context.
Reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade input (0-100).

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: The core logic calculates distance, not a letter grade. There are no conditional statements for grading.

misconceptions.name: Submitted solution for wrong problem
misconceptions.description: Student submitted a complete solution to a different problem (distance between points calculator) instead of the required grade calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were solving the distance-between-points problem, or they accidentally submitted code from a different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade. The submission must match the specified problem.
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grade
Class name is DistanceBetweenPoints instead of something like GradeCalculator
Output shows distance calculation, not letter grade mapping
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread the problem statement, copied code from a different problem, or submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement carefully. Write a new program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100), uses conditional statements to check the appropriate ranges, and outputs the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% certain this is the wrong solution—the code solves a completely different problem with different inputs, different logic, and different output.

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of reading a single numeric grade as required.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Outputs distance calculation instead of letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
